user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_DoReport:
```c
void UtAssert_DoReport(const char *File, uint32 LineNum, uint32 SegmentNum, uint32 TestSeq, uint8 MessageType,
                       const char *SubsysName, const char *ShortDesc)
{
    uint32      FileLen;
    const char *BasePtr;
    char        ReportBuffer[320];

    FileLen = strlen(File);
    BasePtr = File + FileLen;
    while (FileLen > 0)
    {
        --BasePtr;
        --FileLen;
        if (*BasePtr == '/' || *BasePtr == '\\')
        {
            ++BasePtr;
            break;
        }
    }

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer), "%02u.%03u %s:%u - %s", (unsigned int)SegmentNum,
             (unsigned int)TestSeq, BasePtr, (unsigned int)LineNum, ShortDesc);

    UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, ReportBuffer);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtAssert_DoReport:
bool UtAssertEx(bool Expression, UtAssert_CaseType_t CaseType, const char *File, uint32 Line, const char *MessageFormat,
                ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    FinalMessage[256];
    uint32  TestSegmentCount;
    uint32  TotalTestCases;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    ++UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;

    if (Expression)
    {
        CaseType = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS;
    }

    if ((uint32)CaseType < UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX)
    {
        ++UT_SegmentCounters.CaseCount[(uint32)CaseType];
    }

    TestSegmentCount = 1 + UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
    TotalTestCases   = UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    va_start(va, MessageFormat);
    vsnprintf(FinalMessage, sizeof(FinalMessage), MessageFormat, va);
    va_end(va);

    UtAssert_DoReport(File, Line, TestSegmentCount, TotalTestCases, CaseType, CurrentSegment, FinalMessage);

    return Expression;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer), "%02u.%03u %s:%u - %s", (unsigned int)SegmentNum,
             (unsigned int)TestSeq, BasePtr, (unsigned int)LineNum, ShortDesc);
UtAssert_DoReport(File, Line, TestSegmentCount, TotalTestCases, CaseType, CurrentSegment, FinalMessage);
explanation: Only the listed fragments involve calls or uses that can cause reads of C strings or pointer dereferences that depend on well-formed, null-terminated objects and thus may violate Rule 21.17. Specifically, strlen(File) reads through File until a terminator; the subsequent BasePtr arithmetic and the while loop dereference (*BasePtr) based on that length; snprintf reads the strings pointed to by BasePtr and ShortDesc; vsnprintf produces FinalMessage which is later passed as ShortDesc. Other code in the excerpts either (a) declares buffers or scalar variables, (b) performs integer arithmetic or counter updates, (c) uses locking/unlocking and other control flow, or (d) calls UT_BSP_DoText with a buffer that is produced by the snprintf shown above. These other lines do not themselves call the <string.h> functions listed by the rule nor perform unbounded reads of string objects beyond those already highlighted, so they do not need separate investigation for Rule 21.17.
